Sauce galentyne. —Take faire cruste&yogh; o&ftee; broun brede, stepe þem in vinegre, and pu&ttee; þer-to poudre canel, and lete i&ttee; stepe þer-wyþ til it be broun; and þanne drawe it þurwe a straynour .ij. tymes or .iij., and þanne put þer to poudre piper and salte: & lete i&ttee; be sumwha&ttee; stondynge, and not to þynne, & serue forth. Sauce gingyuer. —Take white brede, stepe i&ttee; wiþ vynegre, and draw it .ij. or .iij. tymes þur&yogh; a straynour; and thanne put þer-to salt added in different ink. poudre gingere, and serue forþe. Sauce for a gos. —Take percelye, grapis, clowes of garleke, and salte, and pu&ttee; it in þe goos, and lete roste.  And whanne þe goos is y-now, schake ou&ttee; þa&ttee; is wiþ-in, and put al in a mortre, and do þer-to .iij. harde &yogh;olkes o&ftee; egges; and grynd al to-gedre, and tempre i&ttee; vp wiþ verious, and caste i&ttee; upon the goos in a faire chargeour, & so serue i&ttee; forth. Sauce camelyne. — Take faire brede, and cu&ttee; i&ttee;, and toste it; and take vynegre and wyne, and stepe hi&ttee; þer-in, and draw it þurwe a straynour wiþ poudre canel, and draw it .ij. or .iij. tymes, til it be smothe.  And þanne take poudre ginger, sugre, and poudre of clowes, and cast þer-to.  And loke þa&ttee; i&ttee; stonde wil by clowes, & by sugre; and þanne pu&ttee; þer-to a litil safroune, and salt, and serue hit forþ þicke y-nowe. Sauce rous. —Take brede, and broyl it vpon þe colous, and make it broune, and ley hi&ttee; in vynegre, and lete i&ttee; stepe; and þanne take piper, canel and notemygge&yogh;, and a fewe of clowes, and cas&ttee; i&ttee; to-gedre in-to a mortre; and take þe brede ou&ttee; of þe vynegre, and bray þer-wyþ.  And whanne i&ttee; is y-brayd y-now, tempre i&ttee; wytℏ wyne and vinegre, and draw i&ttee; þurgℏ a straynour as þou woldiste galyntyne. Sauce for stokefysshe. —Take faire broþe of elys, oþer of pyke, or els o&ftee; freysshe Samon, and strayne it þurwe a straynour: and take faire percely, and hewe i&ttee; smal, and put þe broþe and þe percele in-to a faire erþyn vessel; and put þer-to poudre gingere, and a litil verious, & lete boile to-gedre. And þanne take faire sode stockefysche, and ley it in faire hote watre: and whanne þou wilt serue it forþe, take þe fysshe fro þe watre, and ley it in a clene disshe; & cast þe sauce al hote þer-on, and serue it forth. Sauce for stokfysshe in an-other maner. —Take curnylles of walnotys, and clouys of garleke, and piper, brede, and sal&ttee;, and caste al in a morter; and grynde it smal, & tempre i&ttee; up wiþ þe same broþe þa&ttee; þe fysshe was sode in, and serue i&ttee; forþe. Heading in margin. Sauce for peiouns. —Take percely, oynouns, garleke, and sal&ttee;, and mynce smal the percely and þe oynouns, and grynde þe garleke, and temper it wiþ vynegre y-now: and mynce þe rostid peiouns and cast the sauce þer-on a-boute, and serue i&ttee; forth. Sauce for shulder of moton. —Take percely, and oynons, and mynce þem and þe rostyde shulder of Moton; and take vynegre, and poudre gingere, salt, and cas&ttee; a-pon þe mynced shulder, and ete hym so. Sauce vert. —Take percely, myntes, diteyne, peletre, a foil or .ij. o&ftee; cos&ttee;marye, a cloue of garleke.  And take faire brede, and stepe it with vynegre and piper, and sal&ttee;; and grynde al this to-gedre, and tempre it vp wiþ wynegre, or wiþ eisel, and serue i&ttee; forþe. Surelle. —Take Surel, wasche hit, grynde i&ttee;, pu&ttee; a litil sal&ttee;, þer-to, and strayne hi&ttee;, and serue forth. Sauce percely. —Take percely, and grynde hi&ttee; wiþ vynegre & a litel brede and sal&ttee;, and strayne i&ttee; þurgℏ a straynour, and serue i&ttee; forþe. Sauce gauncile. —Take floure and cowe mylke, safroune wel y-grounde, garleke, peper, salt added in different ink. and put in-to a faire litel po&ttee;; and seþe i&ttee; ouer þe fire, and serue i&ttee; forthe with the goos . Piper for feel and for venysoun. —Take brede, and frye i&ttee; in grece, draw it vp wiþ broþe and vinegre: caste þer-to poudre piper, and salt, sette on þe fire, boile i&ttee;, and melle i&ttee; forþe. White sauce for capons y-sode. —Take almoundis y-blaunchid, and grynde þem al to douste; tempre i&ttee; up wiþ verious and poudre of gingere, and melle i&ttee; forþe. Black sauce for capouns y-rostyde. —Take þe Lyuer o&ftee; capouns, and roste hit wel; take anyse, and grynde parysgingere, and canel, and a litil cruste o&ftee; brede, and grynde hi&ttee; we&llbar; a&llbar; to-gedre; tempre hit up wiþ verious, and þe grece of the capon, þanne boile i&ttee; and serue forþe. Sauce newe for malardis. —Take brede, and blode y-boilid, and grynde it to-gedere, and draw þurw a cloþ withe vynegre; do þer-to poudre gyngere, and piper, and þe grece of the malarde; sal&ttee; i&ttee; and boile, and melle it forthe.

0.1: Peynreguson … PAGE 112 Amendment of salt mete … 112 For to make amydon … 112 Teste de cure … 112 Sweteblanche … 112 Rischewys close? … 112 Bukenade … 113 Cyuele … 113 Caudele … 113 Saug saraser … 113 Rape … 113 Egredoucetes … 113 Figee … 113 Pomesmoille … 113 Rys moilles … 113 Apple moys  … 113 Soupes dorrees … 114 Peys de almayne … 114 Tauorsay … 114 Haddoke in Cyuee … 114 Chauudon of fissh … 114 Mortrowes of fissh … 114 Blaumanger of fissh … 114 Potage of ris … 114 Numbles … 114

1.1: Peynreguso&nmacr; —Nym resons & do out ye stones, and bray it in a morter with pepir & gingiuer, & salt and wastel bred; tempre hit with wyn, boille hit, dresse hit forth. Amendement of salt mete. —Tak a fare lynne clout / & do therynne a disshful of ote-mele, byne hit, & hange it in thy pot doun to ye boteme. Set it from ye fuyr & let hit kele / suththe set hit a&yogh;en to ye fuyr / & drawe out thy clout & that is goude. For to make amydo&ntail;. —Nym whete at midsomer / & salt, & do it in a faire vessel / do water therto, that thy whete be yheled / let it stonde ix days & ix ny&yogh;t, & eueryeday whess wel thy whete / & at ye ix days ende bray hit wel in a morter / & drie hit to&yogh;enst ye sonne / do it in a faire vessel / & kouere hit fort, thou wil it note. Teste de cure. —Nym rys, whas hem / drie hem / & bray hem al to doust in a morter, & amydo&nmacr; therwith: tempre it vp with almand mylk / cast therto poudur and safro&nmacr; / & sugur / nym luys, turbot, and elys / & gobete hem in mosselys, & sauge & perceli / mak coffyns of thi past / do thy fissh therynne; cast aboue goud poudur & sugur; kerue it, bake it, and &yogh;if hit forth. Sweteblanche. —Nym chikons or hennes, skald hem, drawe hem in morselys, & seth hem with good beofe.  nym yolkes of eyren ysoden hard / & almande mylk, and grind to-gedere / nym ye floures of ye rede vyne, & salt, & bray al in a morter: boille hit / nym thy chikons or thy he&nmacr;, ondo hem in disshes, do thy sewe aboue / & also my&yogh;t thou do fissh days with lyuere of turbut or of other manere fissh with almand mylke. see p. 55. Ryschewys close? .—Nym flour and eyren, & kned to-gedere/nym figus, resons, & dates, & do out ye stonys, & blanchid almandis, & goud poudur, & bray to-gedere / make coffyns of ye lengthe of a spanne / do thy farsour therynne, in euerych cake his porcio&ntail; / plie hem & boille hem in water / & suththe roste hem on a gridel & &yogh;if forth. Bukenade. —Nym fressh flessh, what it euere be.  Seth hit with goud beof, cast therto mynsed oynons & good spicerie, & lie hit with eyren, & &yogh;if hit forth. Cyuele —Nym almandes, Sugur & salt, & payn de mayn, & bray hem in a morter / do therto eyren, frie hit in oylle or in grese, cast theron sugur, & &yogh;if hit forth. Caudele. —Nym eyren, & sweng wel to-gedere / chauf ale & do therto / lie it with amydo&ntail;, do therto a porcio&ntail; of sugur, or a perty of hony, & a perti of safro&ntail;; boille hit, & &yogh;if hit forth. Saug saraser. i.e. Sauce Sarrasine. —Tak Almandes, frye hem in oille, & bray hem, tempre hem with almand mylke & red wyn, & ye thrudde perty shal be sugur / & if hit be no&yogh;t thikke ynow, lie it with amydo&ntail; or with flour de rys; colour hit with alkinet, boille hit, dresse it, florissℏ hit aboue with pomme-garnet, and &yogh;if forth. Rape. —Nym luyss or tenge, or other manere fissh / frye hit in oille de olyue; nym crostes of whyt bred, resons, & canele, bray hit, tempre it vp with good wyn, drawe it thorw a colonur / let hit be al ycoloured with canele, boille hit, cast therto clous, maces, and quibibes, do thi fissh in thi disshes, & thi rape aboue, messe hit, & &yogh;if forth. Egredoucetes. —Tak luy&yogh;s or tenges, kerf hem in mosselis, fri hem in oille: nym vynegre / & ye thrudde perty sugur, mynce oynons, & boille smal, & clous, maces, & qibibus, & dresse hit forth. Figee. —Nym figes, & boille hem in wyn, & bray hem in a morter with lied bred; tempre hit vp with goud wyn / boille it / do therto good spicere, & hole resons / dresse hit / florisshe it a-boue with pomme-garnetes. Pomesmoille. —Nym rys & bray hem in a morter, tempre hem vp with almande milke, boille hem: nym appelis & kerue hem as small as douste, cast hem yn after ye boillyng, & sugur: colour hit with safro&nmacr;, cast therto goud poudre, & &yogh;if hit forth. Rys moilles. —Nym rys, bray hem, tempre vp with almand mylke: boi&llbar; hem, cast therto sugur / & salt hit, & dresse hit forth. Apple moys. —Nym appeles, seth hem, let hem kele, frete hem thorwe an her syue: cast it on a pot / & on a fless day cast therto goud fat broth of bef,  & white grese, sugur & safro&ntail;, & on fissh days almand mylke, & oille de oliue, & sugur, & safro&ntail;: boille hit, messe hit, cast aboue good poudre, & &yogh;if forth. Soupes dorrees. —Nym oynons, mynce hem, frie hem in oille de olyue: nym oynons, boille hem with wyn, tost whit bred, & do it in dishes / and cast almand mylke thero&ntail;, & ye wyn & ye oynons aboue, & gif hit forth. Peys de almayne. —Nym white peson & boille hem / & thanne tak hem vp, & wash hem clene in cold water, fort that ye holys go of: do hem in a clene pot / do water therto that hit be a-wese / let hem sethe vppo&ntail; colys / that ther be no lye / couere thi pot / that ther go no breth out / whenne hit beth ysode, do hem in a morter & bray hem smal, tempre hem vp with almande milke, & with flour de rys, do therto safro&nmacr; & salt, & boille hit & dresse hit forth. Tauorsay. —Nym ye hed of ye codlyng & ye liuere, & pike out ye bones / cast therto goud poudre of piper & gyngiuer, and gif forth. Haddoke in Cyuee. —Shal be yopened & ywasshe clene / & ysode & yrosted on a gridel; grind peper & saffro&ntail;, bred & ale / mynce oynons, fri hem in ale, & do therto, and salt: boille hit, do thyn haddok in plateres, & thi ciuey aboue, & &yogh;if forth. Chauudo&ntail; of fissh. —Nym ye liuere & ye poke.  Seth hit, hakke hit smal / grind peper & safron, bred & ale, tempre hit with ye broth / boille hit, do salt therto, & messe hit forth. Mortrowes of fissh. —Tak ye rowys of fissh / & ye liuere, seth hit, hakke hit, grind peper, bred & ale, tempre hit with ye broth: do salt therto, boille hit, & messe hit forth. Blaumanger of fissh. —Nym a pond of ris, seth hem fort hit berste, let hem kele: cast therto mylk of two pond of almandes / nym ye perch other ye loppestere or drie haddok, tese therto, and boille hit / cast therto sugur, & &yogh;if forth. Potage of ris. —Nym ye ris, whess hem clene, seth hem fort hit breke: let hem kele, do therto almand mylke, other of kyn, i.e. kine: cow milk . colour it with safro&ntail;, salt hit, & &yogh;if forth. Numbles. —Shall be ywhess clene in water & salt, & ysode in water / nym Cetera desunt .

0.1: Oyle Soppes … lxiij. PAGE  115 Capon en Counfyt … Cij. 115 Cokentrice … Ciij. 115 Crane roste  … Cvij. 116 Fesaunt rost  … Cviij. 116 Heron rost … Cx. 116 Bitore roste … Cxj. 116 Egrett rost … Cxij. 116 Plouer rost … Cxix. 117 Snyte rost … Cxx. 117 Sturgeon buille ou turbutt … Cxlvj. 117 Charlette … Clxxviij. 117

1.0: ¶ Oyle Soppes.  Capitulum lxiiij. —Take and buille mylke, and take yolkes of eyre&ntail; tryed fro the white, and draw hem; then cast to the milke and hete it, butt lete it nat buille, & styrre it we&llbar; ti&llbar; it be summe-whate thikke: then cast ther-to sugre and salte, and cutt feyre paynemayne in soppes, & cast the soppes there-on, & serue it fortℏ in maner of potage.
1.1: ¶ Capo&ntail; en Counfyt.  ¶ Capitulum cij. —Take fressℏ broth, and wy&ntail;, & persely, & saverey, and a lite&llbar; sauge, and lete buille to-gedrys: and crome ther-to herde yolkes of eyre&ntail; ty&llbar; it be we&llbar; thykke, and kest ther-to pouudre of gyngeuere y-nogℏ, & vertious, and salt, and saffro&ntail;; and take a good rosted capo&ntail;, & ley hym in a chargeur, & ryse the legges and the wynges, butt set ham nott fro the body; and kest on the capo&ntail; the licour a&llbar; hotte, & serue it fortℏ.
1.2: ¶ Cokentrice.  ¶ Capitulum ciij. —Scalde a capo&ntail; cle&ntail;, & smyte hem in-to the wast oueretwarde, and scaude a pygge, and draw hym, & smyte hym in the same maner; and then sewe the forthyr parte of the capo&ntail; and the hyndyr parte of the pygge to-gedrys, and the forther parte of the pygge and the hynder parte of the capo&ntail; to-gedyr: then draw the whyte & the yolkes of eyre&ntail;, and cast ther-to, and svette of a schepe, and saffro&ntail;, & salt, and pouudre of gyngeuere, and grated brede; and medle a&llbar; to-gedre witℏ thy&nmacr; honde, and putt it in the cokentrice, and putt it on a spite, and roste hem; and endore hem with yolkes of eyre&ntail;, and pouudre of gyngeuere, and saffro&ntail;, & ioissℏ of persely or malves, & draw hem, and endore hem a&llbar; abowte in euery perty of hy&mtail;.
1.3: ¶ Crane roste.  Capitulum c.vij. —Take a crane, and cutt hym in the rofe of the mouth, and lete him blede to deth: and cast a-wey the blode, and schalde hym, & draw hym vndyr the wynge or att the vent, & folde vpp hys legges att the kneys vndir the thye; & cutt of the wyngys next iunte the body, i.e. cut off the wings at the joint next to the body. and lete hym haue hys heuede & hys necke on; saue take awey the wesyng, and wynde the necke a-boute the spyte, and bynde hit, & putt the bille in the body and the golett; and reyse the wynges and the legges as of a gose; and yiff þou schalt sauce hym, mynce hym fyrst, and sauce hym withe pouudre of pepyr, and gyngeuere & mustarde, vynegre & salt, and serue hym fortℏ.
1.4: ¶ Fesaunt rost.  Capitulum cviij. —Lete a fesaunt blode in the mouth, and lete hym blede to deth; & pulle hym, and draw hym, & kutt a-wey the necke by the body, & the legges by the kne, & perbuille hym, & larde hym, and putt the knese in the vent: and rost hym, & reise hym vpp, hys legges & hys wynges, as off an henne; & no sauce butt salt.
1.5: Hero&ntail; rost.  ¶ Capitulum c.x. —Take an hero&ntail;, & lete hym blode in the moutℏ as an crane, & scalde hym & draw hym att the vent as a crane; and cutt awey the boo&ntail; of the necke, & folde the necke a-boute the spite, and putt the hede ynne att the golet as a crane; & breke awey the boo&ntail; fro the kne to the fote, and lete the skyn be stille, and cutt the wyng att the Joynte next the body, and putt hem on a spite: and bynde hys legges to the spyte with the skynne of the legges, & lete rost, & reyse the legges and the wynges as of a crane, and sauce hym with vynegre, and mustard, and pouudre of gyngeuere, & sett hym fortℏ.
1.6: ¶ Bitore roste.  Capitulum cxj. —Slee a bytour in the moutℏ as an hero&ntail;, & draw hym as an henne, and fold vppe hys legges as a crane; & lete the wynges be on, & take the boo&ntail; of the necke a&llbar; awey as of an hero&ntail;: & putt the hedde in the golet or in the shuldre, and rost hym; and ryse the legges & the wynges as þou dost of an heron, & no sauce butt salt: & sett hym fortℏ.
1.7: Egrett rost.  Capitulum cxij. —Breke an egrettes nekke, or cut the rofe  of hys moutℏ, as of a crane, & scalde hym, and draw hym as an henne; & cutt of hys wynges by the body, and the heued & the necke by the body, & folde hys legges as a bitore, & rost hym: & no sauce butt salt.
1.8: ¶ Plouer rost.  ¶ Capitulum Cxix. —Breke the skulle of a plouere, & pull hym drye, and draw hym as a chike, and cutte the legges and the wynges by the body, and the heued and necke a&llbar;-so, & roste hym, and reyse the legges and wynges as an henne: and no sauce butt salt.
1.9: ¶ Snyte rost.  ¶ Capitulum Cxx. —Slee a snyte as a plouere, & lete hys necke be hole saue the wesyng; and lete hys heuede be on, and putt it in the schuldre, and folde vppe his legges as a crane, & cutt his wynges and roste hym, & reyse hys legges and wynges as an henne; & no sauce butt salt.
1.10: ¶ Sturgeo&ntail; buille ou turbutt.  ¶ Capitulum Cxlvj. Draw a turbutt or a sturgeo&ntail;, and chy&ntail; hym, & cutt the&mtail; in brode pecis; and buille hem in water and salt y-nogh, and serue hym fortℏ colde, a pece or too in a dissℏ with vert sauce: and cast persely leves wette in vynegre on hym. ¶ Charlete.  ¶ Capitulum Clxxviij. —Setℏ melke yn a pott and cast ther-to salt and saffro&ntail;; & hew feyre buttes of calues or of porke sma&llbar;, and cast ther-to: and draw the white & yolkes of eyre&ntail;, and cast to the licour when it builleth, and a lite&llbar; ale, and stirre it ti&llbar; it crudde.  and yiffe þou wilt haue it forced, hete milke scaldyng hoote, and cast ther-to rawe yolkes of eyre&ntail; and poudre of gyngeuere, and sugre & clowes & maces, & lete natt fully buille; and press the cruddes in feyre leny&ntail; cloth, & lessℏ it, & ley too or thre lesshes in a dissℏ: & cast the farsyng ther-on, & serue it forth hote.
